security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing statistical modeling reference material. Contains only Python code examples using the statsmodels library. No executable scripts, no network calls, no file system access beyond its own directory, and no external dependencies. Safe for publication.

content.value_statement: Users need to analyze data with rigorous statistical methods. This skill provides comprehensive guidance for regression models, hypothesis testing, time series analysis, and diagnostic procedures.
actual_capabilities: Fit linear regression models (OLS, WLS, GLS, quantile)
Build generalized linear models (logistic, Poisson, Gamma)
Perform time series analysis (ARIMA, SARIMAX, VAR)
Conduct hypothesis tests and diagnostic checks
Estimate discrete choice models (Logit, Probit, MNLogit)
Compare models using AIC, BIC, and likelihood ratios
limitations: Does not include pretrained models or external data
Requires Python environment with statsmodels installed
No built-in data visualization (external matplotlib required)
Focus on methodology, not automated interpretation

prompt_templates.title: Basic regression
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to fit an OLS regression model using statsmodels with a pandas DataFrame. Include how to add a constant term and interpret the results summary.

prompt_templates.title: Time series
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me build an ARIMA model for time series forecasting. Include how to check stationarity, choose parameters, and generate forecasts with confidence intervals.

prompt_templates.title: Logistic regression
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to fit a logistic regression model in statsmodels for binary classification. Include how to calculate odds ratios and marginal effects.

prompt_templates.title: Model diagnostics
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me perform diagnostic tests on my regression model. Include tests for heteroskedasticity, normality of residuals, and multicollinearity.

output_examples.input: Fit an OLS model predicting house prices from square footage and number of bedrooms.
output: Model Summary shows R-squared of 0.75 indicating 75% variance explained
Square footage coefficient: +250 (each additional sq ft adds $250 to price)
Bedrooms coefficient: +15000 (each bedroom adds $15,000 to price)
P-values both significant at p < 0.05 level
Breusch-Pagan test p-value of 0.42 suggests no heteroskedasticity
Condition number of 12 indicates no multicollinearity concerns

best_practices: Always add constant term with sm.add_constant() for intercept estimation
Check model assumptions using diagnostic tests before interpretation
Use robust standard errors when heteroskedasticity or clustering is present
Validate predictions with cross-validation or holdout data
anti_patterns: Forgetting to add constant term (no intercept in model)
Using OLS for binary outcomes (use logistic regression instead)
Interpreting coefficients without accounting for link function

faq.question: How does statsmodels compare to scikit-learn?
faq.answer: Statsmodels focuses on statistical inference with detailed p-values and diagnostics. Scikit-learn focuses on prediction. Use statsmodels when interpretation matters.

faq.question: What is the maximum model size supported?
faq.answer: Statsmodels handles datasets fitting in memory. Large datasets may require sampling or chunking. Practical limits depend on available RAM.

faq.question: Can I use statsmodels with pandas DataFrames?
faq.answer: Yes, statsmodels integrates seamlessly with pandas. Column names become variable names, and results objects include DataFrame-compatible output.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using statsmodels?
faq.answer: Statsmodels processes data locally in memory. No data leaves your machine. No external connections are made during analysis.

faq.question: Why is my model not converging?
faq.answer: Convergence issues often stem from perfect separation in logistic models, multicollinearity, or scaling problems. Try scaling predictors or using regularization.

faq.question: When should I use GLS instead of OLS?
faq.answer: Use GLS when errors have known non-constant variance (WLS) or are correlated (GLSAR for time series). OLS with robust SEs is often sufficient otherwise.
